questions.text: A 52-year-old man has come to the emergency complaining of a burning type of chest pain. Comment on his ECG recording shown below.
questions.solution:
The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm.

The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows:

  • The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway.

 

  • Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles.

 

  • The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal (<200 ms) in duration.

 

  • The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm.

questions.text: All of the following are supraventricular tachycardias except:
questions.solution:
Premature ventricular beats are a type of ventricular tachycardias, not supraventricular tachycardias.

Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of >100 beats/min. It can be classified based on the site of origin of the cardiac impulse as follows:

  1. Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles, that is, in the sinoatrial node, atria, or the atrioventricular node. Supraventricular tachycardias include:
    • Tachycardias originating from the atrium:
      • Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node
      • Focal atrial tachycardia
      • Multifocal atrial tachycardia
      • Atrial flutter 
      • Atrial fibrillation
    • Tachycardias originating from the AV node:
      • Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node
      • AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT)
    • Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: atrioventricular reentry tachycardia (AVRT)
  2. Ventricular tachycardias originate from the ectopic foci or the reentry pathways in the ventricles. Ventricular tachycardias include:
    • Premature ventricular beats
    • Ventricular tachycardia (VT)
      • Monomorphic VT- Very rapid monomorphic VT is also known as ventricular flutter
      • Polymorphic VT- associated with Torsades de pointes
    • Ventricular fibrillation

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

questions.text: Which is the most common supraventricular tachyarrhythmia?
questions.solution:
The most common supraventricular arrhythmia is sinus tachycardia. It can either be physiological or pathological. Physiological sinus tachycardia is seen in exercise, fever, anemia, hyperthyroidism, etc.

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are those supraventricular tachycardias that occur with sudden onset and termination, they are non-sustained arrhythmias (lasts < 30 seconds). They include AVNRT, AVRT, and atrial tachycardias.

The most common sustained (lasts > 30 seconds) arrhythmia is atrial fibrillation.

Junctional tachycardia originates from ectopic foci in the AV node. It is an uncommon tachycardia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman was brought to the emergency with complaints of dizziness, shortness of breath, and palpitations. ECG showed tachyarrhythmia with narrow QRS complex and irregular RR intervals. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ECG showing tachyarrhythmia with a narrow QRS complex suggests a supraventricular tachycardia. An irregular RR interval is seen with the following supraventricular tachycardias:

  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia
  • Atrial flutter/ atrial tachycardia with variable block

The ECG below shows atrial fibrillation. Note the narrow QRS complexes and irregular RR intervals. Disappearacne of P-wave is another feature.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. 

Risk factors for developing AF include:

  • Age- usually above 60 years of age
  • Underlying heart disease
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Sleep apnea
  • Post-cardiac surgery
  • Inflammatory pericarditis

Acute precipitating factors for AF include:

  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Acute alcohol intoxication
  • Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who is on treatment for chronic AF presents with nausea, dizziness, and anorexia. He has a regular heart rate of 50/min. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
A patient of atrial fibrillation usually has an irregular heart rate of >100/ min but this patient presents with a regular slow heart rate. The most likely cause of slow regular heart rate in chronic AF is digitalis toxicity. Symptoms such as nausea, anorexia are also suggestive of digitalis toxicity.

Digitalis lowers the AV nodal conduction by stimulating the vagal nerve endings leading to increased vagal tone. Hence digitalis toxicity can cause AV nodal block. This leads to a junctional escape rhythm taking over the ventricles causing slow and regular heart rate. 

Digitalis toxicity can also lead to a variety of arrhythmias as it increases the intracellular calcium levels increasing the risk of tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who was brought to the casualty due to severe chest pain followed by syncope is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves, known as flutter waves.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 and a ventricular rate of 68/min.

The image below shows sawtooth shaped waves in atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. 

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Calcium-channel blockers and radiofrequency ablation of the AV node are the other treatment modalities.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

questions.text: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias do not include:
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias do not include atrial fibrillation.

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are tachycardias that occur with sudden onset and termination, they are not sustained arrhythmias. They include

  1. AVNRT
  2. AVRT
  3. Atrial tachycardia

Whereas, atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia among supraventricular tachycardias.

Features suggestive of PSVT:

  • Narrow complex tachycardia at 150 bpm
  • No visible P waves
  • Pseudo R’ waves due to retrograde atrial activation

The given ECG shows pseudo R' waves: 

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the casualty after he developed sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and palpitations at a party. His blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. His ECG is shown below. What is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows:

  • Narrow QRS complexes
  • No visible p waves
  • Pseudo R' waves in V1 lead

Adenosine is the preferred drug in stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). 

Treatment of PSVT:

In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done.

In hemodynamically stable patients,

1. Mechanical measures: These maneuvers result in an acute increase in the vagal tone which decreases AV conduction and terminates the arrhythmia. They include the following:

  • Valsalva maneuver
  • Lowering the head between the knees
  • Coughing
  • Splashing cold water on the face
  • Breath-holding
  • Carotid sinus massage

2. Pharmacologic therapy:

  • Adenosine- it is the first-line agent. It blocks conduction across the AV node and terminates the SVT. It is given as a 6-18 mg bolus 
  • Calcium channel blockers- verapamil and diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers- esmolol, propranolol, and metoprolol
  • IV Procainamide- it is administered if the tachycardia is being mediated through an accessory pathway. It facilitates the AV conduction and therefore causes an initial increase in rate. Therefore, it is given after administering calcium channel blockers or beta-blockers.

 

The given ECG shows pseudo R' waves:

questions.text: The  ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with absent P wave is suggestive of paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next best step in the management of a patient with unstable vitals (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) is synchronized cardioversion.

Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice in unstable PSVT patients, in which shocks are delivered with the defibrillator/monitor in synchronized mode with an initial energy level of 100J. Synchronization times the delivery so that it is given at the peak of the QRS complex.

If the shock occurs in the ST segment or the T wave (unsynchronized), it can precipitate a more serious arrhythmia such as ventricular fibrillation.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation

Used in unstable PSVT, atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, and ventricular tachycardia with a pulse

 Used in ventricular tachycardia without pulse and ventricular fibrillation.
Shock is delivered in sync with the R wave (in absolute refractory period) Shock is delivered at any time during the cardiac cycle.

Monophasic: 100-200 J

Biphasic: 50-100 J

Monophasic: 360 J

Biphasic:120-200 J

Other options:

Option A: In the absence of hemodynamic instability, a repeat dose of injection adenosine (maximum of 12mg) could be attempted.

Option B: IV Amiodarone is rarely used in the acute management of PSVT. Instead, it is used as an alternative to calcium channel blockers in chronic suppressive therapy.

Option D: Defibrillation is only done for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed a narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160 BPM. His blood pressure is 96/68 mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complex regular tachycardia without P waves are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next step in the management of PSVT in a hemodynamically stable (systolic blood pressure >90 mm Hg) patient is vagotonic maneuvres such as carotid sinus massage or Valsalva maneuver.

Carotid sinus massage can be considered in the absence of carotid bruits and no history of stroke. If vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used. 

Non-DHP calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are second-line pharmacological agents in the management of PSVT. They can cause hypotension before and after terminating the arrhythmia.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mm Hg), immediate QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is necessary.

The treatment algorithm for PSVT is described in the flowchart below:

Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an unconscious patient, who is hemodynamically unstable (systolic BP <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mmHg). The ECG shows a narrow QRS complex tachycardia (heart rate of 188 BPM) with regular RR interval and absent P waves, characteristic of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next step in management is QRS-synchronized DC cardioversion.

Shown below is the algorithm for the management of supraventricular tachycardia:

Options A, B, and C are all used in stable cases. Vagal maneuvers like carotid massage or Valsalva are tried first followed by IV Adenosine. If these are ineffective, IV Verapamil, Diltiazem, or Beta blockers are used.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation

Used in sustained VT
Used in SVT (unstable cases), atrial flutter/fibrillation

 Used in VT and VF without a pulse
The shock delivered in sync with R wave (in absolute refractory period) The shock is delivered at any time during cardiac cycle

Characteristics of QRS complex:
Narrow and regular - 50 to 100J
Narrow and irregular - 120 to 200J
Wide and regular - 100J
Wide and irregular - No synchronised cardioversion

Wide and irregular QRS complex
Monophasic: 360 J
Biphasic:1 20-200 J

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: Which of the following is false about accessory pathways?

choices.text: Bundle of Kent has antegrade conduction

questions.solution:
Retrograde conduction via accessory pathways does not cause preexcitation. 

Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways:

Antegrade conduction:

  • Occurs from the atria to the ventricle
  • The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay.
  • This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles and thus a wide QRS complex. 
  • Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT

Retrograde conduction:

  • Occurs from the ventricle to the atria.
  • The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria through the accessory pathway.
  • Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the accessory pathway. 
  • Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory pathway?
questions.solution:
The most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory pathway is orthodromic AV reentry.

Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways:

Antegrade conduction:

  • Occurs from the atria to the ventricle
  • The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay.
  • This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles and thus a wide QRS complex. 
  • Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT

Retrograde conduction:

  • Occurs from the ventricle to the atria.
  • The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria through the accessory pathway.
  • Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the accessory pathway. 
  • Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.

AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT) is not caused by an accessory pathway. It involves tissues with different conduction speeds within the AV node or just adjacent to the AV node, known as the fast pathway and the slow pathway. This is known as dual AV nodal physiology.

questions.text: A patient's ECG shows a short PR interval and delta wave. Additional findings include atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular rate. He is hemodynamically stable. All of the following drugs can be used in the management except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation.

Rate-slowing drugs such as non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, verapamil, diltiazem), beta-blockers, and digoxin are contraindicated in these patients. They increase the refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.

 The ECG below shows a short PR interval (<120 ms) and delta waves in WPW syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: The most common location of the accessory pathway in WPW syndrome is:
questions.solution: The most common location of an accessory pathway in WPW syndrome is on the left free wall. It is present between left atrium and free wall of left ventricle.

questions.text: All are true about the condition that is diagnosed by the given ECG except:

choices.text: Can be seen in asymptomatic individuals
Caused by an abnormal accessory pathway

questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases with age.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is as shown below. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. 

Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).

Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding sick sinus syndrome?

choices.text: Most patients are symptomatic in the early stages
Frequently seen in patients with atrial fibrillation

questions.solution:
Sick sinus syndrome is frequently seen in patients with concomitant atrial fibrillation. 

Sick sinus syndrome (or sinus node dysfunction) is a group of abnormal heart rhythms. It is a disorder of the sinoatrial node caused by impaired pacemaker function and impulse transmission. This leads to a combination of abnormal rhythms, including atrial bradyarrhythmias, atrial tachyarrhythmias, and sometimes a pattern of alternating bradycardia and tachycardia, known as tachy-brady syndrome. These irregular rhythms can cause symptoms such as palpitations, decreased tissue perfusion, subsequent fatigue, lightheadedness, pre-syncope, and syncope. 

The management of sick sinus syndrome includes identifying and correcting reversible factors, as an initial step. 

Some examples of reversible causes of Sinus Node Dysfunction include, 

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Sleep apnea
  • Anti-hypertensive medications eg. Beta-blockers
  • Anti-arrhythmic medications eg. Amiodarone, Procainamide

Ambulatory ECG monitoring is required to diagnose as the symptoms are nonspecific.

Treatment involves permanent pacing. 

Other options:

Option A: The course of sinus node dysfunction is usually a slow progression over decades. In the early stages, most patients are asymptomatic.

Option B: It occurs most commonly in elderly patients due to the gradual loss of SA node function. 

Option D: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in this condition.
